Title: A closed form of the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{H_n^2-(\gamma + \ln n)^2}{n}$
Content:
I have found a closed form of the following new series involving non-linear harmonic numbers. Proposition. $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{H_n^2-(\gamma + \ln n)^2}{n} = \dfrac{5}{3}\zeta(3)-\dfrac{2}{3}\gamma^3-2\gamma \gamma_{1}-\gamma_{2} $$ where      \begin{align} & H_{n}: =\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{k} \\ &\gamma: =\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{k}-\ln n\right) \\ & \gamma_{1}:=\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{\ln k}{k}-\frac{1}{2}\ln^2 n\right)\\& \gamma_{2}: =\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{\ln^2 k}{k}-\frac{1}{3}\ln^3 n\right), \end{align} 
$\gamma_1, \gamma_2$ being Stieltjes constants . What tool would use to prove it?
llm_answer_create_structured_problem:
###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
$H_n$ is defined as $\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{k}$,
$\gamma$ is defined as $\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{1}{k}-\ln n\right)$,
$\gamma_1$ is defined as $\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{\ln k}{k}-\frac{1}{2}\ln^2 n\right)$,
$\gamma_2$ is defined as $\lim_{n\to\infty} \left(\sum_{k=1}^n \frac{\ln^2 k}{k}-\frac{1}{3}\ln^3 n\right)$,
$\gamma_1$ is a Stieltjes constant,
$\gamma_2$ is a Stieltjes constant.
Problem:
Prove that $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{H_n^2-(\gamma + \ln n)^2}{n} = \dfrac{5}{3}\zeta(3)-\dfrac{2}{3}\gamma^3-2\gamma \gamma_{1}-\gamma_{2}.$$
###

Assumption 7: $$H_{n}(s_{1}, \dots, s_{l}) == \sum_{0 < k_{1} < k_{2} < \dots < k_{l} \leq n}\prod_{i = 1}^{l}\frac{1}{k_{i}^{s_{i}}}$$
Problem:
Prove that $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{H_n^2-(\gamma + \ln n)^2}{n} = \dfrac{5}{3}\zeta(3)-\dfrac{2}{3}\gamma^3-2\gamma \gamma_{1}-\gamma_{2}.$$
